basics.name: James Ward
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary:
I am an Engineer through and through - I solve practical problems.
			I get things done, ship amazing software, and create a superb user
			experience - all while hitting every specification and business
			requirement.  Unit tests and general test driven development are
			some of my go-to tools for crafting supreme code in a multitude of
			languages, and I've also dabbled in some end-to-end testing
			frameworks.


			This isn't just a day job to me, it's a passion.
basics.goofySummary:
A mage of code, a warlock of operations, and an overall wizard for
			building up the most fanastic systems you could ever imagine. The
			ally you have dreamed to have. Winning countless battles of wits
			against compilers and interpreters, accomplishing everything
			regulation compliance of an impeccable detail to hardened systems
			capable of withstanding even the most brutal of attacks. I ship
			amazing software, and code I work with becomes stable -
			just like magic. Some call it luck, a roll of the die. In my
			experience, there is no such thing as luck.

work.summary:
Worked with a team to create PHP and Java interoperating
				systems to handle large throughput of data based on various user
				generated rules.

				Extensively used backbone.js and other tools to create a
				maintainable highly interactive client side experience.

				Rewrote portions of a legacy codebase in PHP from classic ASP,
				as well as refactored procedural PHP to a more structured object
				oriented approach.
work.goofySummary:
Battling alongside an armada of other skilled warriors to fend
				off from hordes of network traffic and bugs.  Torrential rain of
				requests from around the globe at a scale never seen before,
				they must all stay courageous and face the eye of the storm.


				Battle is not all in store, however.  In times of peace, the
				hero pursues coding nirvana and encourages others to do so as
				well.  To accept the silence of passing unit tests is to know
				true peace of mind. To code with hidden information is to
				protect against future attacks.  To master the use of XDebug is
				to open the mind's eye and see into the stack itself.

				These are the disciplines our hero teaches.

work.summary:
Refactored of large portions of legacy PHP codebases to
				implement new features, working with several hundred thousands
				of lines of code managed on GitHub.


				Implemented encryption and password hashing systems to meet
				industry standards and ensure PCI-DSS compliance.


				Created unit and integration tests to verify changes would not
				break existing legacy code.


				Performed database administration, systems administration,
				upkeep of internal perl tools, created tools for automation,
				and optimized the web stack to scale as the company did.
				Maintained basic mitigation of denial of service attacks on
				services through caching, network optimization and reverse
				proxies.
work.goofySummary:
Fighting dragons in legacy codebases PHP continues on for this
				adventurer. This time the hero is given ferocious new tools.
				With refactoring as his blade and unit testing his shield, he
				slowly but surely is defeating the beastly bugs within. Already
				having defeated the PCI-DSS kraken, the and continuing the fight
				with the the Denial of Service Hydra, learning new tricks with
				caching and reverse proxies along the way, our handsome
				swashbuckler has saved the kingdom from peril time and again.

work.summary:
Designed and implemented new features, bug fixes, and reduced
				the memory footprint for Accrisoft's flagship Freedom CMS.


				Integrated the CMS with several SOAP and REST APIs.


				Worked alongside a team of talented programmers, using
				subversion and an in-house ticketing system.


				Optimized the standard web stack and configuration installed on
				application nodes, to minimize the required specifications.
work.goofySummary:
Development of Accrisoft's Freedom CMS is the task at hand. A
				never ending quest of solid feature implementation and an
				overhaul of old, legacy code have been undertaken. A side tale
				of integration with a multitude of other products has been
				assigned, as well as vanquishing bugs, increasing performance
				and decreasing memory footprint wherever possible.
